Glycemic Index Of Besan

Besan, also known as gram flour or chickpea flour, is a popular ingredient in Indian cuisine. It is made by grinding dried chickpeas into a fine powder. Besan is not only versatile in cooking but also has several health benefits. One important aspect of its nutritional profile is its glycemic index (GI).

The glycemic index is a measure of how quickly a carbohydrate-containing food raises blood sugar levels. Foods with a high GI are rapidly digested and absorbed, causing a sharp increase in blood sugar levels. On the other hand, foods with a low GI are digested and absorbed more slowly, resulting in a gradual and steady rise in blood sugar levels.

Besan has a relatively low glycemic index, making it a suitable choice for individuals with diabetes or those looking to manage their blood sugar levels. The GI of besan is around 10-15, which is considered low. This means that consuming besan does not cause a rapid spike in blood sugar levels, making it a healthier alternative to refined wheat flour or other high GI flours.

The low glycemic index of besan can be attributed to its high fiber content. Fiber is an indigestible carbohydrate that slows down the absorption of glucose into the bloodstream, resulting in a more gradual rise in blood sugar levels. Besan contains both soluble and insoluble fiber, which not only helps regulate blood sugar levels but also aids in digestion and promotes a feeling of fullness.

Besan is also rich in protein, which further contributes to its low glycemic index. Protein takes longer to digest than carbohydrates, which helps slow down the release of glucose into the bloodstream. This can help prevent blood sugar spikes and promote better blood sugar control.

In addition to its low glycemic index, besan offers several other health benefits. It is gluten-free, making it a suitable option for individuals with gluten intolerance or celiac disease. Besan is also a good source of vitamins and minerals, including iron, magnesium, and folate. These nutrients are essential for various bodily functions, such as energy production, immune function, and red blood cell formation.

Besan can be incorporated into a variety of dishes, making it a versatile ingredient in the kitchen. It is commonly used to make traditional Indian snacks like pakoras and dhoklas, as well as savory pancakes and crepes. Besan can also be used as a thickening agent in soups, stews, and sauces.
